raw_text:
London hope over Chepkemei
 
 London Marathon organisers are hoping that banned athlete Susan Chepkemei will still take part in this year's race on 17 April.
 
 Chepkemei was suspended from all competition until the end of the year by Athletics Kenya after failing to report to a national training camp. "We are watching it closely," said London race director David Bedford. "There is a long way to go before the race and we are hoping the situation will be satisfactorily resolved." The camp in Embu was to prepare for the IAAF World Cross Country Championships later this month. Chepkemei however took part and finished third in last Sunday's world best 10K race in Puerto Rico. The 29-year-old has finished second to Paula Radcliffe in the 2002 and 2003 London races as well as in November's New York City marathon.

Chepkemei was suspended by Athletics Kenya for failing to report to a national training camp, but she finished third in the 10K race in Puerto Rico last Sunday.
She has a history of strong performances at the London Marathon and other major races.

She finished third in the last Sunday's World Cross Country Championships race and has won both New York City marathons and November's New York City marathon as well as the 2002 and 2003 London races.

Despite being suspended by Athletics Kenya, Chepkemei competed and placed third in a world best 10K race last Sunday.
She has previous success at the London Marathon, finishing second in both 2002 and 2003, as well as in November's New York City marathon.
London race director David Bedford says they are hoping the situation will be satisfactorily resolved before the April race.

London Marathon organisers hope Susan Chepkemei will participate this year's marathon on April 17th.

tinyllama:1.1b: London Marathon organizers hope that Chepkemei, who was suspended from competition after failing to report for a national training camp until the end of the year, will still participate in this year's race on April 17th despite a long-standing dispute.
Bedford, director of London Race Director, says there is "a long way to go before the race" and that an "attempt is being made" to "satisfactorily resolve" the situation.
The campaign for Chepkemei's participation, which was announced in October, will have to wait until after the IAAF World Cross Country Championships in Puerto Rico.
Despite finishing third in last Sunday's world-class 10K race, Chepkemei has already participated in two previous London Marathons.
tinydolphin:1.1b: In an unexpected turn of events, Susan Chepkemei, a suspended athlete who had been banned for not reporting to a national training camp, has been allowed to participate in the London Marathon, which is scheduled to take place on April 17th.
However, it remains to be seen how the situation will be resolved, as Athletics Kenya, the organization responsible for disciplinary actions, has yet to make an official announcement.

granite3.1-dense:2b: London Marathon organizers, led by David Bedford, are maintaining optimism that suspended Kenyan athlete Susan Chepkemei will compete in the April 17 event.
Chepkemei was banned until year-end for not attending a national training camp in Embu, intended for the IAAF World Cross Country Championships.
Despite this ban, she recently competed and finished third in a 10K race in Puerto Rico.
Chepkemei has previously impressed at London Marathons, finishing second to Paula Radcliffe in 2002 and 2003, as well as in the 2004 New York City marathon.
